_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Process Description

The water treatment process at the L.T. "Pie" Hay Filter Plant involves the use of chlorine for disinfection purposes in order to provide safe drinking water to the City of Lexington and surrounding communities. Chlorine in its gaseous form is mixed with treated water to form a chlorine solution that is added during the treatment process.

Chlorine is listed by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) as a regulated toxic substance. Facilities that handle amounts of chlorine over 2,500 pounds are required by the EPA to develop a Risk Management Program (RMP) to reduce the risk to employees and the public of injury from an accidental release of chlorine. The L.T. "Pie" Hay Filter Plant stores 4,000 pounds (two 1-ton containers) of chlorine and is therefore required to submit an RMP.  

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The policy of the City of Lexington is that the operation of all chlorine equipment will be by trained and knowledgeable personnel only. Therefore, personnel at the filter plant are required to attend all training as specified in the RMP. The emergency response policy involves providing emergency awareness level training to employees and the cooperation of the facility with the local emergency response agencies. 

Off-Site Consequence Analyses

RMP regulations require the analysis of a worst-case release scenario and an alternative release scenario to determine the area that could potentially be affected by a chlorine release. The EPA defines the worst-case release scenario as ?the greatest amount held in a single vessel ? released as a gas over 10 minutes?. This scenario is highly unlikely, but is used as the basis for the analysis of potential risk involved with the use of regulated chemicals and in the development of the risk management program. The alternative release scenario involves a release that is more likely to occur than the worst-case release scenario.
A computer model p

rovided by the EPA was used to estimate the distance that chlorine could travel and still have an impact on the public and the environment. This model utilizes the parameters required by the regulations, such as specific atmospheric conditions. In addition, the model was run using a "release in enclosed space, in direct contact with outside air". This parameter reduces the rate of release to 55% of the rate of a release happening outdoors.

The worst-case scenario for chlorine analyzed the release of 2,000 pounds of chlorine over a 10 minute period. The model calculated that this worst-case release could potentially affect the public and the environment within a 0.9 mile radius of the filter plant.

For the alternative release scenario, the situation of a leak occurring while connecting a full container was analyzed. The operating steps for this procedure include opening the chlorine container valve slightly, re-closing it immediately and testing for chlorine leaks. Therefore, any leak will be detected and the problem corrected before placing the container in service. The model calculated that under this scenario, the chlorine would travel less than 0.10 mile. This is the minimum distance the model will provide.
 
Accidental Release Prevention Program

The L.T. ?Pie? Hay Filter Plant has developed an accidental release prevention program based on the EPA Risk Management Program and OSHA Process Safety Management regulations that includes the following:
  
  Operating procedures to ensure safe operation of the chlorine equipment 
  Annual operator training regarding the hazards of chlorine, operating procedures, and emergency procedures
  Routine maintenance to prevent mechanical failure
  Leak detector to minimize the effects of an accidental chemical release

Five-Year Accident History

On August 21, 2007 a release of chlorine gas occurred at the L.T. "Pie" Hay Filter Plant. The release was due to a faulty value assembly which allowed gas to escape. Plant personnel

were able to shutoff the chlorine cylinder within two minutes of initial release. It is estimated that less than 10 lbs of chlorine escaped during this time. 

Plant personnel followed established procedures for emergency response by contacting the fire department. Fire department personnel responded to the filter plant and secured the area. Fire department personnel determined that the cylinder had been shutoff and that no leak was present. 

The leak did not cause any injuries to onsite personnel or to any of the adjacent population. There were no damages associated with this accident. 

Emergency Response Program

The L.T. "Pie" Hay Filter Plant is included in the community emergency response plan developed by the Henderson County Emergency Management agency. The primary responder in the event of an accidental chlorine leak is the City of Lexington Fire Department. The filter plant has appropriate procedures in place to notify the fire department when there is a need to respond.
